tn.text: This is the name of one of the mountains in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a city in Moab.

tn.ref: Kiriathaim has been captured and humiliated.
tn.text: "The enemy has captured the city of Kiriathaim and its people can no longer be proud of it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The honor of Moab is no more
tn.text: This means that the respect that Moab enjoyed in the past will be gone.
This is the name of the royal city of the king of the Amorites.
"Madman" is a town in Moab. "Their enemies will destroy the city of Madman" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: a sword will go after you
tn.text: This means an army will invade Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jeremiah continues to tell of the destruction of Moab.
This is the name of a town in the south of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These two terms mean the same thing. Together they emphasize complete destruction. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This refers to the people of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a place in Moab.
AT: "because of the destruction of the town". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "your" refers to the people of Moab.
The people who escape the destruction in the city are compared to a bush which survives the harsh conditions in the desert and has green leaves all year. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
AT: "to live by following the customs and teachings of your religion"
"Chemosh" is the chief god of the Moabites. Here "Chemosh" represents the nation of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: So the valley will perish and the plain will be devastated
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that every part of the land will be destroyed. AT: "So the destroyer will destroy every city in the valleys and on the plains." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

This command is an exaggeration, because no one can put wings on people. Also, the idea of flying away represents the idea of rapidly running away. AT: "Help the people of Moab escape," "It would be good if the people of Moab had wings and could fly away." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "killing people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Moab has felt secure since he was young
tn.text: Here "he" refers to the entire nation of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: He is like his wine that has never been poured from pot to pot
tn.text: The word "he" is the nation of Moab. The nation of Moab is being compared to wine that has not been exiled from its land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Therefore he tastes as good as ever; his flavor remains unchanged
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: So see, the days are coming
tn.text: "Listen carefully because soon"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: tip him over and pour out all his pots and shatter his jars
tn.text: These two phrase are saying similar things and are combined for emphasis. Both of them refer to the oncoming destruction of the nation of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The word "you" means the Moabite soldiers.

tn.ref: How can you say, 'We are soldiers, powerful fighting men'?
tn.text: AT: "No longer can you say, 'We are soldiers, powerful fighting men.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: its finest young men have gone down to the place of slaughter.
tn.text: AT: "Their fine young men will all be slaughtered." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Moab's disaster is soon to happen; calamity is hurrying quickly
tn.text: These two sentences mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Moab's destruction will happen very soon. AT: "Moab's enemies will destroy her very soon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the strong staff, the honored rod, has been broken
tn.text: Here the words "staff" and "rod" refer to the power and political support that Moab provided to other nations. AT: "Moab's enemies have broken her great power." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: sit on the dry ground, you daughter living in Dibon
tn.text: The word "daughter" refers to the people of Dibon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "the enemies of the people of Moab"
AT: "ask the people" or "ask the men and women"
AT: "cry loudly in pain and anger"
These are cities in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: The horn of Moab has been hacked off; its arm has been broken
tn.text: Both 'horn' and 'arm' mean the same thing. They mean that Moab has been injured. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].

The judgments which God sends upon Moab shall allow the country to be scorned by his enemies, just as a drunken man is the object of men's laughter and mocking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Now Moab claps his hands in disgust at his own vomit, so he also has become an object for laughter
tn.text: God continues to compare Moab to a drunken man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For did Israel not become an object for laughter to you?
tn.text: AT: "For you used to laugh at and mock My people in the kingdom of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Was he found among thieves, that you shook your head at him as often as you spoke about him?
tn.text: AT: "Although they were thieves, they were never caught. You shook your head at them scornfully and despised them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
A cliff is a steep side of a mountain.

tn.ref: the mouth of a hole in the rocks
tn.text: This refers to an opening in the rocks, such as the entrance to a cave.

tn.ref: arrogance ... haughtiness ... pride ... self-glory ... conceit in his heart
tn.text: glory ... conceit in his heart** - All of these words have similar meanings. They are used together to emphasize the extreme pride of the people of Moab.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].
to refuse to obey someone or an instruction, sometimes because of pride

tn.ref: I will howl a lament for Moab, and I will shout in sorrow for all of Moab
tn.text: Jeremiah is saying the same thing twice for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a sad and loud cry that a person makes when he is in pain or deep sorrow
This is the name of the old capital city of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are the names of two towns in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: celebration and rejoicing have been taken away
tn.text: AT: "no one will be joyful or happy in Moab now;" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I have put an end to
tn.text: "I have stopped"
"They will not stomp." The word "They" refers to the wine makers of Moab.
This is the name of the royal city of the king of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Elealeh ... Jahaz ... Zoar ... Horonaim ... Eglath Shelishiyah
tn.text: These are names of other cities in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a stream or river near the Dead Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].

tn.ref: my heart is lamenting for Moab like a flute
tn.text: Jeremiah was comparing his feeling to a sad song. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The word "heart" refers to the deep emotions felt by Jeremiah. AT: "I am deeply sad for". (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Kir-heres was an ancient capital of Moab, about 18 kilometers (11 miles) east of the Dead Sea (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: For every head is bald and every beard shaved. Incisions are on every hand, and sackcloth is around their waists
tn.text: These are all things that the people of Moab did when they were mourning or expressing deep sorrow.
cuts made on the skin
"every housetop"
open public areas, such as open marketplaces.
The word "I" refers to Yahweh
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].
demolished or destroyed
a sad and loud cry that a person makes when he is in pain

tn.ref: So Moab will become an object of derision
tn.text: AT: "Moab will become a nation that other nearby nations laugh at"

tn.ref: the enemy will come flying like an eagle, spreading out his wings
tn.text: These phrases compare how a powerful army will descend on Moab and conquer it to the way an eagle swoops down to capture its prey. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a city in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Kerioth has been captured, and its strongholds have been seized
tn.text: "The enemy has captured Kerioth and seized its strongholds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: in that day the hearts of Moab's soldiers ... women in birth labor
tn.text: This phrase compares the fear that will overwhelm the soldiers of Moab to the fear a woman may feel when she is about to give birth to her child. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
AT: "So the enemy will destroy the people of Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here, "year" could be translated as "time" or "season" or "time period."
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].
This refers to the people who were able to run away during the destruction of Moab.
a safe place within the city of Heshbon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: for fire will go out from Heshbon, flame from the middle of Sihon
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings and emphasize that Moab's destruction will begin and spread out from Heshbon. Heshbon was the capital city of the Amorite king, Sihon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the forehead of Moab and the top of the heads of the boastful people
tn.text: These phrases refer to the people of Heshbon and its prominent leaders. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
the part of the face that is above the eyes, but below the hairline. A symbol of pride. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: top of the heads of the boastful people
tn.text: This phrase refers to the prominent people of Moab, such as the princes and leaders. Also a symbol of pride. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

AT: "The people of Chemosh are destroyed by their enemies" or "The enemies of the people of Chemosh destroyed them". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:48:06|48:07]]
This refers to a time in the future, called the "last days."
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|01:8]].
